article.title: Bundling up the Role of the Actin Cytoskeleton in Primary Root Growth

funding.text: Netherlands Organisation for Scientific Research Vici grant
funding.normalized: netherlands organisation for scientific research vici grant

article.abstract: Primary root growth is required by the plant to anchor in the soil and reach out for nutrients and water, while dealing with obstacles. Efficient root elongation and bending depends upon the coordinated action of environmental sensing, signal transduction, and growth responses. The actin cytoskeleton is a highly plastic network that constitutes a point of integration for environmental stimuli and hormonal pathways.

sections.introduction: The root system is an essential part of the plant that navigates the soil for water and nutrients. The primary root is the first organ to emerge from the seed, and therefore, its developmental plasticity is of utmost importance.

article.insights_summary: The actin cytoskeleton plays a crucial role in primary root growth by regulating cell elongation and division. Actin organization is developmentally regulated in the growing root tip, and bundled and longitudinally oriented actin filaments are a hallmark of cell elongation.
